abstracts.cdata!:
The China Higher Education Reform
            Project had a satisfactory outcome, is highly likely to be
            sustainable, and has a substantial institutional development
            impact. Both performances of the Bank and the Borrower were
            satisfactory. The key lessons concerned the need for
            government commitment to large-scale reform of higher
            education; effectively coordinating and integrating
            technical assistance and management when training key
            management and teaching staff; clarifying capacity building
            needs at the national and institutional levels; transforming
            the evaluation system into an internally motivated,
            self-generating agency; establishing guidelines for
            accreditation of higher education institutions; reinforcing
            institutional autonomy with a supportive policy framework
            and financial arrangements, and strong governance;
            competitive bidding in textbook acquisition; balancing cost
            considerations with quality and specifications of service
            standard when procuring precision instruments; and financing
            equipment maintenance with counterpart funding.

5081604.trustfund:
TF025682-PHRD-HIGHER EDUCATION REFORM PROJ.(RECIPIENT-EXEC.),TF039244-CHINA - HIGHER EDUCATION
            MANAGEMENT REFORM SEMINAR,TF025654-PHRD-HIGHER EDUCATION REFORM PROJ.(BANK-EXEC.),TF039243-CHINA - HIGHER EDUCATION PROJECT,TF025394-PHRD-HIGHER EDUCATION REFORM
            PROJ. (BANK-EXEC.),TF037435-CHINA - HIGHER EDUCATION REFORM PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
The Higher Education Reform Project for
            China aims to improve the quality and relevance of
            undergraduate basic science and engineering programs through
            integrated reform activities in curriculum and teaching
            methodology. There are three project components. The first
            a) renews and restructures the science and engineering
            disciplines by reducing narrow specializations,
            restructuring academic programs of study, and introducing
            new integrative science and engineering courses; b) adopts
            student-centered learning strategies, updates textbooks,
            makes laboratories, computer facilities, and library
            resources more readily accessible; and establishes
            well-equipped integrated laboratory centers and c) upgrades
            teachers and staff in support of reforms such as providing
            continuous training and promoting information exchange among
            staff. The second component funds innovative forms of
            cooperation. The third component funds project activities
            that support institutional capacity for change such as a)
            policy-based research studies; b) course and textbook
            revision; c) development of electronic teaching and learning
            materials; d) nationally-organized technical assistance that
            trains implementation personnel; e) overseas study tours and
            workshops; and f) overall coordination, monitoring, and evaluation.
